comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content: About digitalcollections.smu.edu/cdm/singleitem/collection/mex/... I wonder if there were Hondo Mines in México. This picture is rather close linked to Smelter near Durango www.flickr.com/photos/smu_cul_digitalcollections/83860811... in its left lower margin it appears "MEXICAN INTERNATIONAL" In loading coke... you can see a wagon that says "INTERNACIONAL MEXICANO" Ferrocarril Internacional Mexicano, completed the line in 1888, used to run from Porfirio Díaz (Piedras Negras-Eagle Pass), Coahuila to Durango City. This rail road company crossed rails at Torreón with Ferrocarril Central Mexicano, that completed lines in 1883 which joined El Paso, Texas-Paso del Norte (Ciudad Juárez), Chihuahua to México City. The train most likely is in México; notice de Mexican "adobe" (mud tiles) building, most likely crucibles or melting furnaces. Althoug several American mining companies were stablished in México. Roberto Duarte Torreón, Coahuila
